GuyWithNoBrain

read this article and tell me what you think.
 
 Also answer some of the questions:
 Is it ok for a vegetarian to eat clone meat from an animal that has not been killed?
 Would cloning meat solve world wide hunger? End food shortages?
 Would it be able to stop the mass slaughtering of animals for meat?
 Would it be just morally wrong?
 
 Personally I think it would be great. Hopefull it would taste the same as the real thing. And some of my friends are vegetarian who don't eat meat because of the slaughter of animals would probably eat this new clone. Hopefully this would stop the mass killing of animals on farms but I dont think it would solve world hunger. And no I don't think its wrong no animal dies from the cloning.

post_info.post_title: Is it morally right to eat clone meat?

Kronus

I'm a vegetarian, for moral reasons, and I'd probably eat it. My guideline has always been whether or not something died, so this stuff would pass the test.
 
 As for ending world hunger, I'm not optimistic. The causes of famine tend to be more political and logistical than anything else. The US pays farmers not to grow food, so it's not a lack of food that we should be looking at to explain world hunger.
PoohBear

now i have a qusetoin. the clone is still an animal with the same feelings as the other one it was cloned from. so it still is an animal. so i dont know why it would be any different than its cloner other than it porbably costs a couple million dollars more.
joebrummer

now i have a qusetoin. the clone is still an animal with the same feelings as the other one it was cloned from. so it still is an animal. so i dont know why it would be any different than its cloner other than it porbably costs a couple million dollars more.

 
 
 I am thinking you didn't read the article........
 
 There is no animal invovled, it is meat from a test tube!
gnojek
Morals aside, it would be unappetizing to say the least.
Jaxian
Well, I don't find it unappetizing, and I'd bet my vegetarian friends would eat this sort of meat as well. I would probably eat this clone meat out of a respect for vegetarian principles.
Kronus

Morals aside, it would be unappetizing to say the least.

 
 Apparently they stretch the meat as it grows to exercise the cells, otherwise you'ld just end up with goo. Even so it doesn't have the texture of meat. Spam is probably the closest equivalent.
 
 On the other hand, if you use it to make fish sticks or chicken nuggets I don't know if you would be able to tell the difference.
Iuris
Wait a second, you mean there's actually some fish/chicken in those? :p
Tastyfish
I'm assuming he ment the stretching apparatus, whilst the Meat(tm) used used for Steaks(tm).
georged

As for ending world hunger, I'm not optimistic. The causes of famine tend to be more political and logistical than anything else. The US pays farmers not to grow food, so it's not a lack of food that we should be looking at to explain world hunger.

 
 I find it interesting that US farm subsidies (primarily to not grow certain crops for commodity market purposes) continue while in 2005 the US has become a net food importer for the first time in history. All at a time of abnormal US payment imbalance and trade deficit.
Ooaman

It's Tubed Beef instead of Ground Beef!!!
 
Is it ok for a vegetarian to eat clone meat from an animal that has not been killed?
A clone would have to consist of the original enzymes which means DNA which means Blood. A Vegetarian my be able to eat cloned meat but a Vegan couldn't.
 
Would cloning meat solve world wide hunger? End food shortages?
Would they clone more than just beef? Would Chicken/Turkey/Pork/ect. be cloned as well?
 
Would it be able to stop the mass slaughtering of animals for meat?
Read my last two comments. Then, consider my first comment. Where would the Enzymes come from? Do they have a stack pile of beef DNA (or the other meaty animals for that matter?)
 
Would it be just morally wrong?
I don't know, but I thought that picture on the first page of the link was disgusting. Of course, I think uncooked beef (or any meat for that matter) to be revolting. emoticon_ic 
 I want to ask once again, where does the enzymes come from?
Tastyfish

Enzymes come from cells, not the blood. A muscle cell contains all the instructions it needs to grow and will produce the nessary enzymes (as these are vastly too large to cross a cell membrane). 
 As for DNA, it can be extracted without killing the animal easily, especially as its muscle you want and not some internal organ.
Ooaman

As for DNA, it can be extracted without killing the animal easily, especially as its muscle you want and not some internal organ.

 What about people who like to eat cow's liver?
Freedom Fighter

As long as it tastes as good as normal meat, I'm up for it. I mean really the meat you buy now is so alterted with, unless you butcher or hunt your own meat, it probably is the same as it is always. Kinda weird to think about tho...
Tastyfish

What about people who like to eat cow's liver?

 All cells have the all the DNA you need for any cell, all you need is to know which genes have to be turned on.
Obvious Child

If we had this it would very probably replace battery farming, as it would presumably be cheaper, and those concerned about the quality (ethical or taste-wise) of their food tend to go free range, often organic. Personally, I think that eating clone meat in these circumstances would be a great leap from what we have now.
Ooaman

What about people who like to eat cow's liver?

 
All cells have the all the DNA you need for any cell, all you need is to know which genes have to be turned on.

 Before I asked about people who like to eat cow's liver, you said...
 
As for DNA, it can be extracted without killing the animal easily, especially as its muscle you want and not some internal organ.

 I quoted you here and then asked the question becasue the liver is an internal organ. So is what you're saying that getting the cells from the cows shoulder muscle (Assuming that it is beef meat you want) is able to produce the cow's liver cloned for those who do want an internal organ?
 
 Also, would they just clone body parts of only cows or would they clone body parts of chickens too (or other animals that we consume for meat)?
Kronus

Before I asked about people who like to eat cow's liver, you said...
 
 I quoted you here and then asked the question becasue the liver is an internal organ. So is what you're saying that getting the cells from the cows shoulder muscle (Assuming that it is beef meat you want) is able to produce the cow's liver cloned for those who do want an internal organ?
 
 Also, would they just clone body parts of only cows or would they clone body parts of chickens too (or other animals that we consume for meat)?

 
 In theory, you could take any cell from a creature and grow any other cell. In practice, we can't do that yet. If you start with stem cells you could get any cell you like, but aside from that if you want liver you need to start with a liver cell.
 
 And there's no reason you wouldn't be able to apply this technique to any animal.
